Description: Over the last few years, diverse customers from the electric power, petroleum, natural gas, and water infrastructure have partnered with them to gain insight into their critical vulnerabilities and learn mitigation strategies

Paper Name: Cyberthreats, Vulnerabilities and Attacks on SCADA Networks
Type: University of California Berkeley Working Paper
Description: This work discusses the current state of today's Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) networks including information on recent attacks and incidents

Paper Name: Cyber Incidents Involving Control Systems
Description: The Control Systems Security Center (CSSC) uses this documented to evolve a standardized approach to incident reporting and analysis

Paper Name: Industrial Network Security: Securing Critical Infrastructure Networks for Smart Grid, SCADA, and Other Industrial Control Systems
Description: This book examines the unique protocols and applications that are the foundation of industrial control systems, and provides clear guidelines for their protection

Paper Name: Secure Architecture for Industrial Control Systems
Description: This paper provides guidance to those organizations that must secure their ICS systems and networks through a defense-in-depth approach to security, achieved through the identification of key security patterns and controls that apply to critical information security domains

Paper Name: Model-Driven Engineering for Mission-Critical IoT Systems
Description: They discuss how Model-driven engineering (MDE) can help meet the technical challenges of MC-IoT system development and runtime management

Paper Name: Transforming trace information in architectural documents into re-usable and effective traceability links
Description: In this paper they describe a technique and supporting tools for extracting and generating traceability links from the architectural documents

Paper Name: A Position Study to Investigate Technical Debt Associated with Security Weaknesses
Description: They present a position study with a five-step approach employing the Quamoco quality model to operationalize the scoring of architectural Common Weakness Enumerations (CWEs)

Paper Name: Components of Industrial Control Systems
Description: They begin the discussion of ICS security by introducing the basic components of ICSs, their functions, variety, and ways in which they connect and interact to produce the intended effects

Paper Name: Educational Modules in Industrial Control Systems for Critical Infrastructure Cyber Security
Description: In order to assess the impact of educational modules on CIS and ICS students, a survey is developed to measure the understanding of the unique aspects of ICS cyber security both before and after module presentation and lab participation

Paper Name: Security of Cyber-Physical Systems
Description: The research presented in this paper discusses some actions towards the development of a replicable and affordable cyber-physical testbed for training and research

Paper Name: Forensics in Industrial Control System: A Case Study
Description: In this paper they present a case study of forensics in ICS where they describe a method of safeguarding important volatile artefacts from an embedded industrial control system and several other sources

Paper Name: A Proposed Australian Industrial Control System Security Curriculum
Type: Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences
Description: This paper proposes a postgraduate curriculum of four courses to provide knowledge and skills to protect critical infrastructure industrial control systems

Paper Name: Research on firmware vulnerability mining technology of power industrial control terminal
Description: This paper makes an in-depth research on the security risk detection technology of power terminals, and puts forward the method of security detection of power terminal-industrial control terminal

Paper Name: The Global State of Security in Industrial Control Systems: An Empirical Analysis of Vulnerabilities Around the World
Description: In this work, the presence of OT(Operational Technology)-devices in the Internet is analyzed from an attacker's perspective

Paper Name: Built-In Cybersecurity: Insights Into Product Security for Cyberphysical Systems at a Large Company
Description: This article is written from the perspective of a practitioner and addresses several components of product security that work together to build security into cyberphysical systems

Paper Name: Automated Characterization of Software Vulnerabilities
Description: In this study, they demonstrate that Vulnerability Description Ontology (VDO) characteristics can be automatically detected from the textual descriptions included in Common Vulnerability and Exposure (CVE) reports

Paper Name: Automating the early detection of security design flaws
Description: This paper focuses on design inspection and explores the potential for automating the application of inspection rules to speed up the security analysis

Paper Name: Learning from Vulnerabilities - Categorising, Understanding and Detecting Weaknesses in Industrial Control Systems
Description: In this paper, they analyse 9 years of ICS Advisory vulnerability announcements and they recategorise the vulnerabilities based on the detection methods and tools that could be used to find these weaknesses

Paper Name: Is It Dangerous to Use Version Control Histories to Study Source Code Evolution
Description: They collected data from 24 developers: 1652 hours of development, 23,002 commited files, and 314,085 testcase runs. They used this data to investigate how much code evolution data is not stored in Version Control Systems

Paper Name: Ãvol: A tool for defining and planning architecture evolution
Description: They demonstrate a tool to enable architects to describe evolution paths, associate properties with elements of the paths, and perform tradeoff analysis over these paths

Paper Name: Evaluating architectural stability using a metric-based approach
Description: This paper proposes a metric-based approach to evaluate architectural stability of a software system by combining predictive- and retrospective evaluation

Paper Name: Visualizing Software Architecture Evolution Using Change-Sets
Description: They present an alternative approach that provides a lightweight method for examining the net effect of any set of changes on a system's architecture

Paper Name: Differencing and Merging of Architectural Views
Description: They propose an approach based on structural information by generalizing a published polynomial-time tree-to-tree correction algorithm (that detects inserts, renames and deletes) into a novel algorithm to additionally detect restricted moves and support forcing and preventing matches between view elements

Paper Name: A systematic review of software architecture evolution research
Description: In this work, they present a systematic review of architecting for software evolvability. The objective of this review is to obtain an overview of the existing approaches in analyzing and improving software evolveability at architectural level, and investigate impacts on research and practice

Paper Name: Architecture, design, implementation
Description: They formalize the Intension and the Locality criteria, which imply that the distinction between architecture, design, and implementation is qualitative and not merely quantitative

Paper Name: Just Enough Software Architecture: A Risk-Driven Approach
Description: This book teaches risk-driven architecting, democratizes architecture, cultivates declarative knowledge, emphasizes the engineering, and provides practical advice

Paper Name: Ref-Finder: a refactoring reconstruction tool based on logic query templates
Description: This paper presents a Ref-Finder Eclipse plug-in that automatically identifies both atomic and composite refactorings using a template-based refactoring reconstruction approach

Paper Name: MADMatch: Many-to-Many Approximate Diagram Matching for Design Comparison
Description: They present MADMatch, a fast and scalable many-to-many approximate diagram matching approach based on an error-tolerant graph matching (ETGM) formulation

Paper Name: Language Support for Connector Abstractions
Description: In this paper, they add language support for user-defined connectors to the ArchJava language

Paper Name: DeMIMA: A Multilayered Approach for Design Pattern Identification
Description: They present DeMIMA, an approach to identify semi-automatically micro-architectures between implementation and design

Paper Name: Clone detection using abstract syntax trees
Description: This paper presents simple and practical methods for detecting exact and near miss clones over arbitrary program fragments in program source code by using abstract syntax trees

Paper Name: Comparison and Evaluation of Clone Detection Tools
Description: This paper presents an experiment that evaluates six clone detectors based on eight large C and Java programs

Paper Name: An Empirical Study of Function Clones in Open Source Software
Description: They examine more than 15 open source C and Java systems, including the entire Linux Kernel and Apache httpd, and analyze their use of cloned code in several different dimensions, including language, clone size, clone location and clone density by proportion of cloned functions

Paper Name: An investigation of cloning in web applications
Description: They are conducting a systematic study of cloning in Web Applications of different sizes, developed using a range of Web technologies, and serving diverse purposes

Paper Name: Domain Analysis of Device Drivers Using Code Clone Detection Method
Description: This paper introduces a new approach to the domain analysis of device drivers

Paper Name: Using clone detection to manage a product line
Description: This position paper sketches a work just started, to review the clones found in a Java-based 250K SLOC web application and determine their impact on the current product and its next generation, currently being planned

Paper Name: CCFinder: a multilinguistic token-based code clone detection system for large scale source code
Description: This paper proposes a new clone detection technique, which consists of the transformation of input source text and a token-by-token comparison

Paper Name: A Survey on Software Clone Detection Research
Description: In this paper, they survey the state of the art in clone detection research

Paper Name: Survey of Research on Software Clones
Description: This report summarizes the author's talk on software clone detection research

Paper Name: A language independent approach for detecting duplicated code
Description: In this paper they apply a language independent and visual approach, i.e. a tool that requires no parsing, yet is able to detect a significant amount of code duplication

Paper Name: Identifying redundancy in source code using fingerprints
Description: A prototype implementation of a machanism that uses fingerprints to identify exact repetitions of text in large program source trees has been built and successfully applied to a legacy source of over 300 megabytes

Paper Name: Efficient randomized pattern-matching algorithms
Type: IBM Journal of Research and Development
Description: They present randomized algorithms to solve the following string-matching problem and some of its generalizations: Given a string X of length n (the pattern) and a string Y (the text), find the first occurrence of X as a consecutive block within Y

Paper Name: On finding duplication and near-duplication in large software systems
Description: This paper describes how a program called dup can be used to locate instances of duplication or near-duplication in a software system

Paper Name: IEEE Standard for Modeling and Simulation High Level Architecture--Framework and Rules
Description: This document provides an overview of the High Level Architecture (HLA), defines a family of related HLA documents, and defines the principles of HLA in terms of responsibilities that federates (simulations, supporting utilities, or interfaces to live systems) and federations (sets of federates working together) must uphold

Paper Name: Power laws, Pareto distributions and Zipf's law
Description: Here they review some of the empirical evidence for the existence of power-law forms and the theories proposed to explain them

Paper Name: Code clones in feature-oriented software product lines
Description: They conduct an empirical analysis on ten feature-oriented software product lines with respect to code cloning

Paper Name: Extending the reflexion method for consolidating software variants into product lines
Description: In this paper, they describe a method and supporting tools to compare software variants at the architectural level extending the reflexion method to software variants

Paper Name: Three decades of software reference architectures: A systematic mapping study
Description: This work presents a panorama on existing software reference architectures, characterizing them according to their context, goals, perspectives, application domains, design approaches, and maturity, as well as the industry involvement for their construction

Paper Name: OO Design Quality Metrics - An Analysis of Dependencies
Type: Workshop Pragmatic and Theoretical Directions in Object-Oriented Software Metrics
Description: This paper describes a set of metrics that can be used to measure the quality of an object-oriented design in terms of the interdependence between the subsystems of that design

Paper Name: Ranking reusability of software components using coupling metrics
Description: This paper provides an account of new static measures of coupling developed to assess the reusability of Java components retrieved from the internet by a search engine

Paper Name: Layer assessment of object-oriented software: A metric facilitating white-box reuse
Description: In this work they propose a new metric facilitating the reuse of object-oriented software based on the popular Chidamber and Kemerer suite for object-oriented design

Paper Name: Recommending source code for use in rapid software prototypes
Description: In this paper, they represent a system for rapid prototyping that facilitates software reuse by mining feature descriptions and source code from open-source repositories

Paper Name: Detecting design flaws via metrics in object-oriented systems
Description: In this paper, they present a metrics-based approach for detecting design problems, and they describe two concrete techniques for the detection of two well-known design flaws found in the literature

Paper Name: A Bayesian Approach for the Detection of Code and Design Smells
Description: The detection and correction of code and design smells have drawn the attention of both researchers and practitioners who have proposed various approaches to detect code and design smells. However, none of these approaches handle the inherent uncertainty of the detection process. They propose a Bayesian approach to manage this uncertainty

Paper Name: Are all code smells harmful? A study of God Classes and Brain Classes in the evolution of three open source systems
Description: It is claimed that classes that are involved in certain code smells are liable to be changed more frequently and have more defects than other classes in the code. They investigated the extent to which this claim is true for God Classes and Brain Classes, with and without normalizing the effects with respect to the class size. They analyzed historical data from 7 to 10 years of development of three open-source software systems

Paper Name: The evolution and impact of code smells: A case study of two open source systems
Description: This study investigates two code smells, God Class and Shotgun Surgery, by analyzing the historical data over several years of development of two large scale open source systems

Paper Name: Identifying thresholds for object-oriented software metrics
Description: This paper presents results of a study on the structure of a large collection of open-source programs developed in Java, of varying sizes and from different application domains. The aim of this work is the definition of thresholds for a set of object-oriented software metrics, namely: LCOM, DIT, coupling factor, afferent couplings, number of public methods, and number of public fields

Paper Name: Sourcerer: mining and searching internet-scale software repositories
Description: Here they first develop Sourcerer, an infrastructure for the automated crawling, parsing, fingerprinting, and database storage of open source software on an Internet-scale. In one experiment, they gather 4632 Java projects from SourceForge and Apache totaling over 38 million lines of code from 9250 developers

Paper Name: Software Product Quality Metrics: A Systematic Mapping Study
Description: A Systematic Mapping (SM) study was carried out on 70 articles and conference papers published between 2009 and 2019 on Software Product Quality Metrics (SPQM) as indicated in their titles and abstract

Paper Name: Planning for Untangling: Predicting the Difficulty of Merge Conflicts
Description: In this work, they aim to predict the difficulty of a merge conflict so as to help developers plan their conflict resolution

Paper Name: An Empirical Examination of the Relationship between Code Smells and Merge Conflicts
Description: They mined 143 repositories from GitHub and recreated 6979 merge conflicts to obtain metrics about code changes and conflicts

Paper Name: On the Interplay between Non-Functional Requirements and Builds on Continuous Integration
Description: It is part of the MSR conference, so it is already analyzed

Paper Name: Metrics and statistical techniques used to evaluate internal quality of object-oriented software: A systematic mapping
Description: This paper presents results of applying a systematic mapping to identify the most software metrics cited and the most statistical techniques/models used to evaluate quality in OO software

Paper Name: Understanding Code Smells in Android Applications
Description: They analyze an open-source corpus of 500 Android applications (total of 6.7M LOC) and 750 desktop Java applications (total of 16M LOC), and compare 14,533 instances of code smells in Android applications to 117,557 instances of code smells in desktop applications

Paper Name: An Empirical Study of Design Degradation: How Software Projects Get Worse over Time
Description: They conducted an empirical study on the presence and evolution of code smells, used as an indicator of design degradation in 220 open source projects

Paper Name: How Does Context Affect the Distribution of Software Maintainability Metrics
Description: Here they aim to investigate if the distributions of commonly used metrics do, in fact, vary with six context factors: application domain, programming language, age, lifespan, the number of changes, and the number of downloads

Paper Name: On the measures for ranking software components
Type: Innovations in Systems and Software Engineering
Description: In this paper, they propose a component ranking approach that models the component graph of a system as a Discrete-Time Markov Chain and uses it as a basis for component ranking

Paper Name: The shape of feature code: an analysis of twenty C-preprocessor-based systems
Description: They analyze the statistical distribution of three feature-related metrics collected from a corpus of 20 well-known and long-lived C-preprocessor-based systems from different domains

Paper Name: If Your Version Control System Could Talk ...
Description: Version control systems (VCSs) are used to store and reconstruct past versions of program source code. As a by-product they also capture a great deal of contextual information about each change. They will illustrate some ways to use this information to better understand a program's development history

Paper Name: CVS release history data for detecting logical couplings
Type: International Workshop on Principles of Software Evolution
Description: They describe a method for software evolution analysis. It consists of three complementary steps, which form an integrated approach for the reasoning about software structures based on historical data: 1) the quantative analysis uses version information for the assessment of growth and change behavior; 2) the change sequence analysis identifies common change patterns across all system parts; and 3) the relation analysis compares classes based on CVS release history data and reveals the dependence within the evolution of particular entities

Paper Name: Predicting source code changes by mining change history
Description: They have developed an approach that applies data mining techniques to determine change patterns - sets of files that were changed together frequently in the past - from the change history of the code base

Paper Name: Mining version histories to guide software changes
Description: They apply data mining to version histories in order to guide programmers along related changes: "Programmers who changed these functions also changed. . ."

Paper Name: Assessing software archives with evolutionary clusters
Description: In this paper they describe their history-based approach to (automatically) assess the extent in which a certain partition allows its parts to evolve independently

Paper Name: A survey and taxonomy of approaches for mining software repositories in the context of software evolution
Type: Journal of Software Maintenance and Evolution: Research and Practice
Description: A comprehensive literature survey on approaches for mining software repositories (MSR) in the context of software evolution is presented

Paper Name: Preprocessing CVS data for fine-grained analysis
Description: It is part of the MSR conference, so it is already analyzed

Paper Name: Detecting groups of co-changing files in CVS repositories
Description: In this paper, they propose a definition of co-changes suitable of practical application. They assess the challenges arising in detection of groups of co-changing software parts, and they present a robust approach, based on dynamic time warping, to detect groups of co-changing files in CVS repositories

Paper Name: Visual data mining in software archives
Description: In this paper they discuss how standard visualization techniques can be applied to interactively explore the data mining techniques rules that can be extracted from software archives

Paper Name: EvoLens: lens-view visualizations of evolution data
Description: Their approach called EvoLens is a visualization approach for explorations of evolution data across multiple dimensions

Paper Name: Studying the Evolution of Software Systems Using Change Clusters
Description: In this paper, they present an approach that examines the evolution of code stored in source code repositories

Paper Name: Logical Coupling Based on Fine-Grained Change Information
Description: They present several new logical coupling measures taking into account fine-grained semantic changes. They evaluate their respective accuracy compared to the classical logical coupling measure on two case studies; in particular, they evaluate how well the new measures can estimate logical coupling with less data

Paper Name: Understanding quality in conceptual modeling
Description: The authors examine attempts to define quality as it relates to conceptual models and propose their own framework, which includes a systematic approach to identifying quality-improvement goals and the means to achieve them

Paper Name: The Darwin Project: Evolvability of Software-Intensive Systems
Description: This paper presents the Darwin project. This applied research project is currently conducted at Philips Medical Systems and focuses on the evolvability of software-intensive systems, with as use case magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) systems

Paper Name: Analysis of Symbolic Data: Exploratory Methods for Extracting Statistical Information from Complex Data
Description: This chapter explores cluster analysis

Paper Name: Extracting Dependencies from Software Changes: An Industry Experience Report
Description: In this paper they report their experience from extracting dependency information from the change history of a commercial software system

Paper Name: Resolving unwanted couplings through interactive exploration of co-evolving software entities -- An experience report
Description: In this paper they discuss how interactive visualizations can support the process of analyzing the identified unwanted couplings

Paper Name: Experiences in evolvability research
Description: In this paper they share obtained experiences, insights, and results. They have collected some evidence that three of the vision's cornerstones, which are about knowledge, i.e., extracting knowledge, representing knowledge, and economic decision making, improve evolvability

Paper Name: Transferring Evolutionary Couplings to Industry
Description: In this chapter, they describe a case study at Philips Healthcare MRI focusing on evolutionary couplings analysis, i.e., a technique to infer relationships among modules by analyzing their history of changes in the source code archive

Paper Name: Toxic Code Snippets on Stack Overflow
Description: They present a study of online code clones on Stack Overflow and their toxicity by incorporating two developer surveys and a large-scale code clone detection

Paper Name: SOTorrent: reconstructing and analyzing the evolution of stack overflow posts
Description: It is part of the MSR conference, so it is already analyzed

Paper Name: Attribution Required: Stack Overflow Code Snippets in GitHub Projects
Description: In this paper, they present the research design and summarized results of an empirical study analyzing attributed and unattributed usages of SO code snippets in GitHub projects

Paper Name: Determinants of quality, latency, and amount of Stack Overflow answers about recent Android APIs
Description: They empirically study Stack Overflow questions pertaining to new Android APIs and their associated answers

Paper Name: On code reuse from StackOverflow: An exploratory study on Android apps
Description: To better understand the impact of code reuse from StackOverflow, they perform an exploratory study focusing on code reuse from StackOverflow in the context of mobile apps

Paper Name: Are Code Examples on an Online Q&A Forum Reliable?: A Study of API Misuse on Stack Overflow
Description: This paper presents an empirical study on the prevalance and severity of API misuse on Stack Overflow

Paper Name: Metrics for class cohesion and similarity between methods
Description: In this paper, they will present a new metric for class cohesion based on similarity between the methods of a class

Paper Name: A Precise Method-Method Interaction-Based Cohesion Metric for Object-Oriented Classes
Type: ACM Transactions on Software Engineering and Methodology
Description: In this paper, they propose a formula that precisely measures the degree of interaction between each pair of methods, and they use it as a basis to introduce a low-level design class cohesion metric (LSCC)

Paper Name: An experimental search-based approach to cohesion metric evaluation
Description: They propose a novel experimentation technique, based on search-based refactoring, to 'animate' metrics and observe their behaviour in a practical setting. Their aim is to provide metrics to the level of active, opinionated objects that can be compared experimentally to uncover where they conflict, and to understand better the underlying cause of the conflict

Paper Name: Understanding the Working Habits of GH-SO Users on GitHub Commit activity and Stack Overflow Post Activity
Type: International Journal of Software Engineering and Knowledge Engineering
Description: They investigate the working habits of GH-SO users on GitHub commit and Stack Overflow post activities

Paper Name: Statistical Modelling of Data on Teaching Styles
Type: Journal of the Royal Statistical Society
Description: This paper presents the detailed statistical modelling of an extensive body of educational research data on teaching styles and pupil performance

Paper Name: Deriving an approximation algorithm for automatic computation of ripple effect measures
Description: This paper describes the reformulation of Yau and Collofello's ripple effect algorithm focusing on the computation of matrix Zm which holds intramodule change propagation information

Paper Name: Object-Oriented Analysis and Design With Applications
Description: This is the essential reference for anyone who implements or manages object technologies, or who wishes to begin exploration of this important new paradigm

Paper Name: Seeking the ground truth: a retroactive study on the evolution and migration of software libraries
Description: They present a retroactive study into the presence and nature of API incompatibilities between several versions of a set of Java-based software libraries; for each, they perform a detailed, manual analysis to determine what the correct adaptations are to migrate from the older to the newer version

Paper Name: Applied Regression Analysis and Generalized Linear Models
Description: This book provides in-depth coverage of regression analysis, generalized linear models, and closely related models

Paper Name: Capturing the Long-term impact of changes
Description: The goal of this thesis is to explore the long-term impact of changes by detecting dependencies between code changes and by measuring their influence on software quality, software maintainability, and development effort

Paper Name: Hubs, authorities, and communities
Description: They ask the question: "What are the recurring patterns of linkage that occur across the Web as a whole?"

Paper Name: An empirical study of software reuse vs. defect-density and stability
Description: This paper describes results of an empirical study, where some hypotheses about the impact of component size on defects and defect-density in the context of reuse are assessed, using historical data (data mining) on defects, modification rate, and software size of a large-scale telecom system developed by Ericsson

Paper Name: A farewell to Bonferroni: the problems of low statistical power and publication bias
Description: Here, the author highlights and discusses an implication of a low statistical power on one of the most widely used statistical procedures, Bonferroni correction

Paper Name: The PageRank Citation Ranking: Bringing Order to the Web
Description: This paper describes PageRank, a mathod for rating Web pages objectively and mechanically, effectively measuring the human interest and attention devoted to them

Paper Name: What's wrong with Bonferroni adjustments
Description: This paper advances the view, widely held by epidemiologists, that Bonferroni adjustments are, at best, unnecessary and, at worst, deleterious to sound statistical inference

Paper Name: Measuring software library stability through historical version analysis
Description: In this paper, they evaluate how stable a set of frequently used third-party libraries is in terms of method removals, implementation change, the ratio of change in old methods to change in new ones and the percentage of new methods in each snapshot

Paper Name: The Maven repository dataset of metrics, changes, and dependencies
Description: It is part of the MSR conference, so it is already analyzed

Paper Name: Multilevel Analysis: An Introduction To Basic And Advanced Multilevel Modeling
Description: This book introduces the main methods, techniques, and Issues Involved in carrying out multilevel modeling and analysis

Paper Name: Combining Modelling Strategies to Analyse Teaching Styles Data
Description: This paper combines two estimation procedures: Iterative Generalized Least Squares as used in the software MLwiN; Gibbs Sampling as employed in the software BUGS to produce a modelling strategy that respects the hierarchical nature of the Teaching Styles data and also allows for the endogeneity problems encountered when examining pupil progress

Paper Name: A generalized model for visualizing library popularity, adoption, and diffusion within a software ecosystem
Description: In this paper, they propose the Software Universe Graph (SUG) Model as a structured abstraction of the evolution of software systems and their library dependencies over time

Paper Name: Trusting a library: A study of the latency to adopt the latest Maven release
Description: In this paper, they investigate the trust of OSS libraries. Their study of 6374 systems in Maven Super Repository suggests that 82% of systems are more trusting of adopting the latest library release to existing systems
